section.title: Description
section.t: SRv6 as designed has interest from various sectors, though is deployment is being limited by the fact that there are known security problems in the protocol design. This document specifies a standard to create a solution that closes some of the major security concerns, while retaining the basis of the SRv6 protocol.

section.title: The SRv6 Security Problem
section.t: SRv6 relies in its architecture on the concept of limited domain which is too vague a concept to form a solid security base.
Limited domains that fail can open, can, and will, invariably leak beyond the domain due to human error.
As per RFC8402 Section 8, SRv6 that leaks beyond the border of a trusted domain creates a security violation.
The solution is to create a trusted domain that has a default fail-closed approach/
Exmaples of fail closed protocols currently include: mpls/clns/llpd/bier

section.title: Characteristics of a Fail-Closed Protocol Domain
section.t: A fail closed protocol domain is determined by following properties:
Processing of the protocol packet on an interface requires explicit configuration with default drop behavior.
Leaking of protocol packets beyond the boundary of fail-closed domain requires explicit config.
Fail closed protocols must be identifiable by their top level (e.g. link layer) encoding.
Classification of the protocol must be deterministic.
Confining the protocol to the trusted domaim must not require complex processing in either hardware or software, so as to allow for scalability.
The boundary of a trusted domain consists of a set of interfaces that exhibit default behavior.

section.title: SRv6 in the context of a trusted domain - an objective analysis
section.t: It is currently impossible to differentiate SRv6 and IPv6 at the link-layer

In the event of a frame being sent into a trusted domain, either accidently or by a malicious actor, it is possible to send the frame to a node binding the specific SID, and have the packet processed, irrespective of the content of the underlying (encapsulated) frame

The current security proposals in RFC8402 section 8.2, security is based on the application of filters preventing ingress traffic at the boundary routers destined towards a SID within the domain. Such filtering is prone to configuration errors and in addition, has significant impact on TCAM utilization on devices that have large numbers of ingress points into the domain

In the context of a trusted domain, anything outside of the operators control should not be considered trusted. This means applying filters to prevent leakage into the domain at every customer port, every server, and every cloud stack. Any lapse in the filters can cause grevious harm

section.title: Trusted-Domain Implementation
section.t: To implement SRv6 in the context of a trusted domain, it is necessary to create a fail-closed scenario. To do this, requires modification of the protoccol at both the boundary routers nd the transit nodes
